<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Aureus (Coin) Portraying Empress Sabina  
A.D. 134, issued by Hadrian  
Gold; diam. 1.9 cm; 7.10 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Bust of Sabina right, draped, diademed; hair waved up in crest  
Inscribed: SABINA AVGVSTA  
Reverse: Juno stands left, veiled, patera in right hand extended over peacock, left rests on scepter  
Inscribed: IVNONI REGINAE  
RIC II 394; BMCRE III 937–39; axis: 6:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4873

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Sabina was Trajan’s great-niece, and for Hadrian, an important link to that respected prince. Trajan’s wife, Plotina, a supporter of Hadrian, had arranged their marriage, which took place around A.D. 100. The marriage of Sabina and Hadrian was childless, and although the nature of their private relationship remains unclear, later sources purport that they shared a mutual distaste for one another, and that Hadrian treated Sabina rather shabbily. However, Hadrian honored her in the customary manner by acknowledging her as Augusta in A.D. 128 and even ordered her posthumous deification, an event celebrated with the first known depiction of an imperial woman’s apotheosis. Sabina also accompanied Hadrian on many of his extensive travels throughout the empire, both before and after he became ruler of Rome. With her mother, Matidia, grandmother Marciana, and great-aunt Plotina, Sabina enjoyed the company of educated and cosmopolitan men and women in Rome. These included the biographer Suetonius, whom Hadrian is reported to have sent away from the court for having been too friendly with her.

Hadrian began minting coins in Sabina’s name after he was honored with the title pater patriae in A.D. 128. In 133 he seems to have assigned her direction of one officina or workshop of the mint—signaled by the appearance of her name alone on the obverse of this coin. The coin was minted soon after they returned from the great tour of the empire in 134.

Sabina’s coin portraits include a variety of hairstyles. On earlier issues her hair is arranged in contemporary styles, also seen on portraits of her mother and grandmother—emphasizing the family resemblance, and thus Hadrian’s right to rule through his adoption by Trajan. On this coin, she had herself portrayed with a simpler hairdo, identified as Greek in style, reflecting the philhellene tastes of the imperial court under Hadrian. Perhaps by this point the imperial couple no longer felt the need to defend the legitimacy of Hadrian’s reign, the success of which, by now, spoke for itself.

An alternative possibility would support the hypothesis that Sabina felt underappreciated. Her long, austere hairdo on this coin bears a notable resemblance to that seen on coins of Agrippina the Elder (d. A.D. 33), granddaughter of Augustus and wife of the greatly admired general Germanicus (see cat. 37, Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Gaius (Caligula)). Agrippina, a woman of excellent character, had died exiled and wronged by Emperor Tiberius. Is it possible that the likeness was intentional, and that Sabina meant herself to be seen as yet another noblewoman who suffered from the unfairness of imperial men?

On this coin she is associated with the queen of the gods; the inscription reads “[To] Juno the Queen.”  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

This is the likeliest date. Thorsten Opper, however, suggested that Sabina might have received the title as early as A.D. 119, following the death of her mother, Matidia: Opper, Hadrian: Empire and Conflict, p. 203. The title of Augusta was the highest honor that could be conferred on a woman of the imperial family. It was not automatically the title of the consort of the emperor but could be held by his sisters, his mother, and other female relations.

The relief sculpture is in the Musei Capitolini, Museo del Palazzo dei Conservatori, Rome, inv. MC1213. Sabina’s deification was also represented on coins.

Burns, Great Women of Imperial Rome, pp. 125, 128, 135.

See Hill, Dating and Arrangement, p. 3. It is intriguing to think of the mechanisms by which coin portraits were decided. Women or other members of the imperial family who controlled officinae of the mint, such as Sabina and Faustina I, may have had no say in monetary policy but a great deal of freedom to choose portraits, reverse types, and inscriptions.
